bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Rojas, May 5, 1948

div1.p: Hench outlines his plans for the memorialization of Camp Lazear. He hopes the Ignacio Rojas daybook will be deposited in the Camp Lazear museum, if it is built.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Rojas, May 5, 1948
div1.opener:
May 5, 1948
Senorita Maria Teresa Rojas
Quinta San Jose
Calle Real, Quemados de Marianao
Cuba
My dear Senorita Rojas:
div1.p:
I was delighted to hear recently that the Cuban Government set
aside $50,000 for the memorial at Camp Lazear. I enclose a carbon of a
letter I sent recently to the Minister of Public Works, also a sketch of
my ideas on the memorial. This should interfere not the slightest with
the Quinta San Jose. I am so sorry that Mrs. Hench and I could spend so
little time with you. I had hoped we could have a longer visit and I had
hoped to ask you a few questions. Since my return I have been so busy I
have not had time to set them down and hope to do so in the near future and
you were kind enough to say that you would answer them.

Mrs. Hench and I were also sorry to learn of your mother's passing.
I had looked forward to seeing her. You, your mother and Miss Cabrerra have
all been very kind to us.

Did I ever send you the enclosed reprint, “Conquerors of Yellow Fever”?
Should you wish more, I have an ample supply.

If the Government does build a little museum, I do hope that you
will be willing to deposit therein your father's day-book or at the very least
a photostatic copy thereof. After all, it was your father's book which gave
the final convincing proof of the location of Camp Lazear on the Finca San
Jose.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
